required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The BabyGrow Longitudinal Study of Nutrition and Growth in Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: The BabyGrow Longitudinal Study of Nutrition and Growth in Preterm Infants

brief_summary.textblock: This is a longitudinal, observational study on nutrition, growth and body composition in preterm infants. Aims to determine the adequacy of actual nutrient intake during the preterm period by investigating associations between macronutrient supply, growth, and body composition at 34-weeks gestation, term equivalent and 2-month corrected gestational age.

detailed_description.textblock: Infants between 23 and 24 weeks gestation and with a birth weight of 500 to 1500 g are recruited to a longitudinal, observational study of nutrition, growth and body composition in Cork University Maternity Hospital, Ireland.

primary_outcome.measure: Actual nutrient intake vs recommended nutrient requirements in preterm infants
primary_outcome.description: Comparison of intake with requirements during the preterm infant's hospital stay and up to 2 months corrected gestational age.

secondary_outcome.measure: Longitudinal data on body composition in Irish preterm neonates
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluation of appropriateness of current feeding regimens for achievement of optimal growth & body composition outcomes

secondary_outcome.measure: Longitudinal data on vitamin D intake and circulating 25(OH)D
secondary_outcome.description: To examine the relationship between vitamin D intake and serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and biomarkers of calcium handling by analysis of sequential serum samples.

study_pop.textblock: Preterm infants admitted to Cork University Maternity Hospital Neonatal Unit

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Babies with a birth weight ≤1.5kg and gestational age ≤34 weeks were considered eligible.
Exclusion Criteria:
- presence of congenital abnormalities or conditions that interfere with growth or body composition (congenital diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, chronic lung disease, cardiac or gastrointestinal diseases).
